title: Ukrainian president responds to Trump impeachment inquiry: 'It is impossible to pressure me'
text:
Mike Pence, the US vice president, meets Ukraine's leader in Warsaw on September 1 - VIA REUTERS

Ukraine's president said on Tuesday that no one explained to him why millions of dollars in US military aid to his country was delayed, shrugging off suggestions that President Donald Trump froze the funding to pressure Ukraine to investigate Democratic rival Joe Biden.

Volodymyr Zelenskiy is struggling to distance himself from US politics, and to contain the damage to Ukraine and his own reputation from a July phone call between him and Mr Trump that unleashed a congressional impeachment inquiry.

"It is impossible to put pressure on me," he told reporters on Tuesday.

"Many people try to influence me but I am the president of independent Ukraine."

Mr Zelenskiy said that in discussions with Mr Trump, he repeatedly stressed the importance of the US military aid to help Ukraine battle Russian-backed separatists.

The leader of Ukraine, speaking in his country's parliament in August More

In the July call, he thanked Mr Trump for his "great support in the area of defense" and said Ukraine was ready to "cooperate for the next steps," according to a rough transcript released by the White House.

Mr Zelenskiy didn't say on Tuesday whether the issue was raised in other discussions or when they took place.

The Pentagon in June announced plans to send $250 million in aid to Ukraine, but its delivery was delayed. A defence official said the Trump administration was analysing the extent to which Ukraine was addressing long-standing US concerns about corruption.

The funding was then released in September.

"It wasn't explained to me" why the money didn't come through earlier, Mr Zelenskiy said.

Mr Zelenskiy also said he has never met or spoken with Mr Trump's lawyer Rudy Giuliani, who has been pushing for Ukraine to investigate Hunter Biden's role on the board of Ukrainian gas company Burisma.

Mr Zelenskiy is facing a dilemma over how to handle Mr Trump's request in the July call for Ukraine to "look into" the Bidens.

Donald Trump meets his Ukrainian counterpart during the UN General Assembly in New York in September More

If Ukraine opens an investigation into the case, that helps Mr Trump and the Republicans. If it doesn't, that helps the Democrats. And what Ukraine's current leadership really wants is continued US support, no matter who wins next year's US elections.

A former Ukrainian security chief argued on Tuesday that the best way to show that Ukraine is serious about fighting endemic, crippling corruption is to open new investigations into Burisma.

Story continues
description: Ukraine's president said on Tuesday that no one explained to him why millions of dollars in US military aid to his country was delayed, shrugging off suggestions that President Donald Trump froze the funding to pressure Ukraine to investigate Democratic rival Joe Biden.
